conflict.translation[0].definitions[0].d: a state of disagreement or argument between people, groups, countries etc
conflict.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Marx points out the potential conflicts below the surface of society.
His views on the literal truth of the Bible brought him into conflict with other Christian leaders.
Doctors exercise considerable power and often come into conflict with politicians.
a lawyer specializing in conflict resolution
social and political conflict in the 1930s
the threat of industrial conflict in the coalfields
the conflict between tradition and innovation
normal kids who are in conflict with their parents
conflict.translation[0].definitions[1].e: For years the region has been torn apart by armed conflicts.
UN troops intervened to avert a threat of violent conflict.
conflict.translation[0].definitions[2].d: a situation in which you have to choose between two or more opposite needs, influences etc
conflict.translation[0].definitions[2].e: As women increasingly went out to work, the possibility of a conflict of loyalties became stronger.
a conflict between the demands of one’s work and one’s family
The principles of democracy are sometimes in conflict with political reality.
conflict.translation[0].definitions[3].d: a situation in which you have two opposite feelings about something
conflict.translation[0].definitions[4].d: something that you have to do at the same time that someone wants you to do something else
conflict.translation[0].definitions[4].e: I’ve got a conflict on Friday. Can we make it Monday?
conflict.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: come into conflict with somebody
Local people have often come into conflict with planning officials.
bring somebody into conflict with somebody
Some of her actions have brought her into conflict with her managers.
cause/create/provoke conflict
Sometimes very small disagreements can cause conflict within a family.
resolve a conflict
You may need a lawyer to resolve a serious conflict between neighbours.
avoid conflict
The prime minister wants to avoid a conflict over the issue.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + conflict
political/social conflict
Widespread unemployment often leads to social conflict.
industrial conflict
The industrial conflict resulted in a series of strikes.
ethnic/racial conflict
The ethnic conflict in the region has become violent.
family conflict
There are various techniques you can use to try and avoid family conflict.
bitter conflict
The new law provoked bitter conflict.
a source of conflict
Lack of money is often a source of conflict between spouses.
an area of conflict
There may be many areas of conflict between parents and teenagers.
conflict resolution
The children are learning methods of conflict resolution to use on the playground.
conflict.translation[1].definitions[0].d: if two ideas, beliefs, opinions etc conflict, they cannot exist together or both be true
conflict.translation[1].definitions[0].e: new evidence which conflicts with previous findings
conflict.translation[2].definitions[0].d: a state of disagreement between people, groups, countries etc
conflict.translation[2].definitions[0].e: The General Strike was the most important industrial conflict of British inter-war history.
They are both strong-willed managers, and associates have noted signs of conflict between them.
conflict.translation[2].definitions[1].d: a situation in which you have to choose between two or more different needs
conflict.translation[2].definitions[1].e: the conflict between housing the poor and minimizing taxpayer costs
